awd_titl_txt: Strategies:  Seeding the Future of STEM researchers through emerging agricultural technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers at Boston College will engage high school aged youth in a three-year pathway framework that will engage the youth in conducting authentic scientific research. The project will involve emerging agricultural technologies like transparent soil (a recent discovery which is a hydrogel that behaves like soil), a near-peer and college-focused mentoring model, and interaction with scientists. The youth will learn to build and code Raspberry Pis (small and affordable computers that students can use to learn programming) to share their data with agronomists and plant scientists. The outcome goal for this work is to prepare youth to enter a post-secondary institution with strong research skills through experience in conducting careful, rigorous scientific research. Throughout the three-year project, youth will be engaged in the same type of scientific research that is occurring at the university level. Specifically, youth will learn: (i) to build the tools (sensors connected to Raspberry Pi and sensors connected to the Internet of Things web infrastructure provided by IBM Watson software system) they will use to collect their data, (ii) to carry out a rigorous scientific investigation (identifying questions, as well as finding and minimizing experimental containments, and determining dependent vs. independent variables), and (iii) to develop models and potential explanations based on their data in collaboration with practicing scientists. The program will recruit low-income youth, and youth from populations underrepresented in science from high schools in Boston Public Schools and support them in learning core scientific research skills and engage them in building the tools they will use to conduct their more complex experiments. The program will not only build the capacity of the youth participants to make potential scientific discoveries, but through the mentoring program youth leaders and mentors will become role models to youth in their community.

There are four major aspects of the proposed work. First, youth will engage with cutting edge technologies being used in scientific research labs. Second, a diverse team of collaborators will be assembled consisting of STEM career development experts, Youth Mentoring experts, Scientists, and Science Educators to design the proposed work. Third, the program is a unique combination of three synergistic components: (1) a near-peer mentoring approach, (2) STEM learning, and (3) youth purpose and career development. Unlike other out-of-school STEM programs, this program will not only support the learning of STEM concepts, but it will do so by taking youth on a personal journey designed to help them discover the relevance of STEM skills for fulfilling future career aspirations, as well as preparing them for post-secondary education. Fourth, the data that youth will share with practicing scientists has the potential to help answer important questions in plant science regarding how plants, particularly their root structures, react to environmental stressors. The research approach provides an opportunity to examine how such constructs as purpose, critical consciousness, and work volition impact youths' intentions to pursue a STEM field. To date, these important constructs have not been seriously considered in STEM career development. Thus, the research on the impact of near-peer mentoring and youths' adaptability and intentionality to explore, pursue, and stay in STEM fields will provide the ITEST community with an evidence-based model integrating near-peer mentoring, scientific research, and STEM career development to elucidate how youth may successfully pursue a STEM field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Overview of the Project

In this project we developed a professional development model and corresponding curriculum materials to support middle and high school science teachers to infuse computational science into their existing curriculums. This work is crucial because most schools that serve low-income youth and youth who have been historically excluded from STEM (our target populations) are often under pressure to cover specific science concepts to prepare their students for standardized testing. That means, the teaching of skills and knowledge around automation and computation is highly unlikely to occur unless it is integrated into the curriculum materials that meet their core content standard goals.  To support teachers in meeting these goals we developed a low-cost version of transparent soil, which is a polymer that mimics the physical and chemical structures of soil yet allows one to see and study root structure without damaging them.  Using transparent soil students can now investigate how environment conditions impact roots not just leaves.  To manipulate their environmental conditions, we developed a mini-desktop greenhouse where students program micro-controllers and sensors to monitor and to manipulate the environmental conditions such as increasing temperature and humidity or manipulating the conditions of the soil.

Intellectual Merit

The driving research questions were for our work were

  1. How does project participation impact youth interest toward coding.
  2. Do student characteristics like gender, race/ethnicity, prior coding interest/experience create differences in outcomes?
  3. Does the teachers' coding experience and comfort level influence students’ interest in coding?

 

Initially the project started with us training teachers using micro-python (a text-based approach to coding) given the physical computing nature of the curriculum we were developing.  During this phase of the project we found that the teachers often struggled in troubleshooting problems as they emerged in the classroom.  As it became easier to undertake physical computing with block-based languages we shifted to block-based programming and adopted the micro-bit as the micro-controller for the project. We also shifted our professional development from an institute model to a hybrid approach which proved to be extremely successful.  In this latter model teachers would attend an intensive set of trainings and then they would participate in summer or semester long trainings on the coding on-line.  This approach, according to the teachers provided them time to think through the coding aspects of the project and to better think about how to bridge the science concepts with the coding concepts in their teaching.  Even with the relatively intensive training we found that it would often take a teacher two years before they would make a pedagogical shift in their teaching to using coding as a tool to engage in science investigations. However, once teachers became comfortable with the coding they explored and experimented with pedagogical approaches to teach coding and science together.

In terms of student outcomes we found that students who rated themselves as not-interested in science, or not a “STEM person” experienced the greatest gains with the lowest quartile of students on the pre-surveys where they showed significant gains on interest, self-efficacy toward science and coding, and their STEM identity.  We found that all students who participated increased across our measures, particularly Hispanic youth.  However, for the youth who entered the project already with high interest and efficacy toward science and coding we saw no gain or decreases in scores but no significant changes. These results suggest that physical computing can serve as an anchor to engage students, particularly those who are leaning toward opting out of a STEM trajectory of study.  In terms of curriculum adaption, the teachers noted that the project offered students multiple entry “interest” points in that a student could be fascinated by the physical computing, or the coding, or the science of plants. This latter finding speaks to the importance of designing transdisciplinary learning experiences as they can enable students to find their own engagement hooks that can motivate them to learn more about STEM.

 

Broader Impacts

Throughout the project our work focused recruited teachers who taught in schools whose student population were predominately lower-income, underrepresented in STEM fields, or did not speak English as their first language.  Over the course of the grant we worked with teachers from six different urban districts across Massachusetts and two implementation sites in Louisiana and over that time we worked with 45 different teachers which corresponds to 4,500 students over the course of the project.  We found that for many of these students this project was their first introduction to physical computing and using computational tools to investigate scientific questions.  The impact of the of the project was most profound for those students who entered the project reporting that they were not considering studying computer science, not interested in science, or did not consider the

Modified by: George M Barnett

    Ludovico Cademartiri
